info.title: Disclaimer
info.content: This OMT App is intended for professional use only. It is based on the most recent update of the OMT (JHSA, 2020). The App provides a brief description of each condition but the information is not intended to be used as an official guideline in the management of congenital upper limb and hand differences. We do not bear any responsibility for the use of this App in patient management. User discretion is advised.

info.title: Key Features and Functionality
info.content:
1) The App is based on the latest version of the OMT (Goldfarb et al., 2020, JHSA). Information contained in this App will be updated to reflect ongoing changes in the OMT Classification and our improved knowledge of each condition, as necessary. 

2) Searching for a condition - You can search for a condition by scrolling down the list as per normal or you can search for it by typing in the name of the condition. Each condition will be described by its OMT classification, description and our current understanding of etiology. 

3) Searching with Key Words - For those who are not familiar with the scientific terms of a condition, the search can be conducted with key words, e.g. for syndactyly, search for fused, joined or webbed fingers. 

4) Images & Radiographs - We have included images (and radiographs where appropriate) for each condition. Please note that the image library is not yet completed. Loading of images is internet-dependent. Each image is regularly checked for its accuracy in relation to the condition. 

5) Syndromes - The fourth part of the OMT is Syndromes. Each Syndrome is described by OMT Classification, hallmark features, current understanding of genetic aetiology and associated hand anomalies. We have also included the Online Mendelian Inheritance in Man (OMIM) link for that condition, which would connect directly to the website. 

6) Tutorial Video - We have produced a tutorial video on how to maximise your use of this App.

labels: Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb (Early Patterning)

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Proximal-distal axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Disproportionate shortening of the upper limb with shortening of fingers

info.title: Etiology
info.content: A condition that resulted from a developmental error in the proximal-distal axis. This axis is regulated by the apical ectodermal ridge (AER). May include AER-related FGFs.

I-A-1-ii-a.title: Symbrachydactyly Spectrum (with ectodermal elements) > Poland Syndrome

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Proximal-distal axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Congenital condition typically defined by absence of the sternal part of the pectoralis major muscle on affected side. Numerous other associated congenital abnormalities of the affected upper limb including symbrachydactyly of the hand including Sprengel’s shoulder (high scapula on one side) and symbrachydactyly

info.title: Etiology
info.content: A condition that resulted from a developmental error in the proximal-distal axis. This axis is regulated by the apical ectodermal ridge (AER). According to some investigators, the primary defect in Poland Syndrome may be impaired development of the subclavian artery resulting in diminished or interrupted blood flow during early embryonic growth around the sixth week of embryonic development.

I-A-1-ii-b.title: Symbrachydactyly (with ectodermal elements) > Whole limb affected excluding Poland Syndrome (various levels - humeral to phalangeal)
tags: Whole limb affected excluding Poland Syndrome

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Proximal-distal axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Condition characterised by shortened upper limb with nubbins or remnant digits. Rudimentary nub-bins may be present which could include elements of the nail plate, bone, and cartilage. In addition the arm or forearm can also be shortened or displays abnormal development. Typically associated with Poland syndrome (see condition listed below)

info.title: Etiology
info.content: A condition that resulted from a developmental error in the distal mesoderm of the proximal-distal axis. This axis is regulated by the apical ectodermal ridge (AER). It is postulated there may be an early insult to the AER during development, but distal ectodermal elements continue to develop, leading to the formation of ‘nubbins’ (small digits with skin and nail). Vascular mechanism hypothesized, but molecular deficit not excluded.

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Proximal-distal axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Complete congenital absence of upper limb

info.title: Etiology
info.content: A condition that resulted from a developmental error in the proximal-distal axis. This axis is regulated by the apical ectodermal ridge (AER). It is postulated there may be an early insult to the AER during development, leading to complete failure of development of the upper limb. In humans, a homozygous WNT loss of function mutation is associated with tetra-amelia. In animal models, homozygous absence of other molecule also cause tetra-amelia such as Fgf10 (required for the AER-Fgf8 - Fgf10 positive feedback loop critical to limb outgrowth), and both Sp6 & 8 (required for AER function.

I-A-1-iii-b.title: Transverse Deficiency (without ectodermal elements) > Segmental (various levels - humeral to phalangeal)

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Proximal-distal axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Condition where all elements of the upper limb beyond a certain level are absent, and there is efffectively an amputation at this level. It can be sub-classified based on the level of deficiency as listed in the conditions below. Note: presence of remnants such as nubbins beyond the level of deficiency suggests a diagnosis of sym-brachydactyly rather than transverse deficiency.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: A condition that resulted from a developmental error in the proximal-distal axis. This axis is regulated by the apical ectodermal ridge (AER). This could occur any time points during early limb development with a suspected sudden complete loss of AER function leading to complete truncation of the upper limb at various levels. In animal models removal of the AER truncates limbs in a progressive fashion (earlier truncation more proximal transverse deficiency). The loss aborts limb development and no terminal ectodermal elements are present. Transverse deficiencies within the humerus early stage, handplate late stage.

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Proximal-distal axis

info.title: Description
info.content: A condition where a segment of the upper limb is absent (arm/forearm) with a remnant hand. The segments missing can be at various levels. In this instance, the short forearm directly attached to trunk with absence of proximal upper limb (Frantz and O'Rahilly type III). There are recent opinions that phocomelia is part of a severe longitudinal deficiency rather than a true segmental, transverse deficiency.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: A condition that resulted from a developmental error in the proximal-distal axis. This axis is regulated by the apical ectodermal ridge (AER). In this condition, an early insult to the AER led to interruption of upper limb development at the humeral level but the limb continued to grow distally with formation of forearm and hand (which are usually hypoplastic). Also, suspected disruption in limb segment-specific genes. Each limb segment has specific genes that promote limb segment-specific development. For example upper arm - MEIS1, SHOX2, forearm - HOXA11, SHOX, and handplate - HOXA13, HOXD13.

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Proximal-distal axis

info.title: Description
info.content: A condition where a segment of the upper limb is absent (arm/forearm) with a remnant hand. The segments missing can be at various levels. In this instance, the short humerus attached to hand with absence of forearm (Frantz and O'Rahilly type II). There are recent opinions that phocomelia is part of a severe longitudinal defciency rather than a true segmental, transverse deficiency

info.title: Etiology
info.content: A condition that resulted from a developmental error in the proximal-distal axis. This axis is regulated by the apical ectodermal ridge (AER). In this condition, a medium-term insult to the AER led to interruption of upper limb development at the forearm level but the limb continued to grow distally with formation of hand (which is usually hypoplastic). Also, primary disruption in proximal-distal axis. Suspected disruption in forearm-specific genes. Each limb segment has specific genes that promote limb segment-specific development. For example upper arm -MEIS1, SHOX2, forearm - HOXA11, SHOX, and handplate - HOXA13, HOXD13.

I-A-1-iv-c.title: Intersegmental Deficiency (Phocomelia) > Proximal + Distal (hand to thorax)

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Proximal-distal axis

info.title: Description
info.content: A condition where a segment of the upper limb is absent (arm/forearm) with a remnant hand. The segments missing can be at various levels. In this instance, the hand directly attached to trunk with absence of arm and forearm (Frantz and O'Reilly type I). There are recent opinions that phocomelia is part of a severe longitudinal deficiency ratehr than a true segmental, transverse deficiency.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: A condition that resulted from a developmental error in the proximal-distal axis. This axis is regulated by the apical ectodermal ridge (AER). In this condition, a very early insult to the AER led to interruption of humeral and forearm development but the limb continued to grow distally with formation of hand (which is usually hypoplastic).Also, primary disruption in proximal-distal axis. Suspected disruption in upper arm-specific genes. Each limb segment has specific genes that promote limb segment-specific development. For example upper arm - MEIS1, SHOX2, forearm - HOXA11, SHOX, and handplate - HOXA13, HOXD13.

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Proximal-distal axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Extremely rare condition where the entire limb is duplicated or triplicated. A very proximal split of the limb can also manifests in a similar way (see above)

info.title: Etiology
info.content: A condition that resulted from a primary error in induction of proximal distal axis. Suspect disruption in body segemention or ectopic expression of upper limb induction molecules such as TBX5. Embryo is segmented in a cranial to caudal fashion by HOX transcription factors, which permit different body segment-specific organs to develop. TBX5 is critical for upper limb induction, while TBX4 & PITX1 are necessary for hindlimb induction.

labels: Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb (Early Patterning)

I-A-2-i.title: Radial Longitudinal Deficiency
tags: Radial Longitudinal Deficiency – Thumb hypoplasia (with proximal limb involvement)

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Radial-ulnar (anterior-posterior) axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Spectrum of upper limb abnormalities where the radial part of the upper limb does not form proper-ly: e.g., radial aplasia (radial club hand) with an associated thumb hypoplasia (shortend or smaller thumb). Associated with Fanconi’s anaemia, Holt-Oram Syndrome, VACTERL association and TAR syndrome. Sub-classification radius (Bayne & Klug): I (shortened radius <2mm); II (shortened radius missing distal epiphysis; III (shortened radius missing proximal epiphysis); IV (absent radius) Sub-classification thumb (Blauth): I (smaller thumb); II (unstable MCP joint); III (A&B depending on CMC joint); IV (floating thumb); V (absent thumb)

info.title: Etiology
info.content: A condition that resulted from a developmental error in the radial-ulnar axis. This axis is regulated by the zone of polarizing activity (ZPA) via the sonic hedgehog (SHH) axis. Most recent updates suggest that suppression of radial growth is the result of increased amounts of SHH from the ZPA and also ectopic SHH on the anterior limb bud. This condition would have resulted from a relatively early event in limb development during formation of the forearm structures.

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Radial-ulnar (anterior-posterior) axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Spectrum of upper limb abnormalities where the ulna does not form properly resulting in a short-ened forearm with an ulnarly deviated hand and abnormal carpal bones. Compared to radial longi-tudinal deficiency, the elbow is more severely affected. Abnormalities of the hand are common, with usually absent digit. The thumb can also be affected. Also known as ulnar club hand.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: A condition that resulted from a developmental error in the radial-ulnar axis. This axis is regulated by the zone of polarizing activity (ZPA) via the sonic hedgehog (SHH) axis. It can be postulated that ulnar elements did not form due to an insult to the ZPA during early limb development. Digit formation, which is closely dependent on SHH, is often affected as well.

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Radial-ulnar (anterior-posterior) axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Rare condition characterised by duplication of forearm with hand involvement. The radial ray is usually absent, with duplication of the ulna. Involvement of the hand would include duplicated ulna carpal bones, metacarpals and phalanges resulting in a symmetric polydactyly. Also known as Mirror Hand.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: A condition that resulted from a developmental error in the radial-ulnar axis. This axis is regulated by the zone of polarizing activity (ZPA) via the sonic hedgehog (SHH) axis. Most recent updates suggest that increased ‘ulnarisation’ (formation of two ulnae instead of radius/ulna) and mirror formation of digits is the result of greatly increased amounts of SHH from the ZPA and also ectopic SHH on the anterior limb bud at a very early stage, although others suggest this is a malformation at a pre-patterning stage.

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Radial-ulnar (anterior-posterior) axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Rare condition in which the elbow is held in fixed flexion due to abnormal connection between the humerus and radius. It can exist with, or without ulnar longitudinal dysplasia.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: Primary disruption in anterior-posterior (radial-ulnar) patterning. Frequently associated with ulnar longitudinal deficiency. Disruption in restricting endochondral cartilage formation by a cytochrome p450 enzyme has also been linked to radiohumeral synostosis.

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Radial-ulnar (anterior-posterior) axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Spectrum of abnormalities which are characterised by an abnormal connection of the proximal radius and ulna at birth. Typically presents with absent forearm pronation and supination.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: Primary disruption in anterior-posterior (radial-ulnar) patterning. Disruption in HOXA11, a forearm-specific gene, has been linked to radioulnar synostosis. The loss in HOXA11 is thought to reduce limb width and length, promoting fusion at the proximal end of the forearm.

I-A-2-vi.title: Congenital Dislocation of the Radial Head
tags: Congenital Dislocation of the Radial Head

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Radial-ulnar (anterior-posterior) axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Almost always a posterior dislocation of the radial head, often combined with bowing and shorten-ing of the ulna and abnormalities of the radial head. Most common congenital abnormality of the elbow.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: Primary disruption in anterior-posterior (radial-ulnar) patterning. Mechanism and gentic basis unclear.

I-A-2-vii.title: Forearm hemi-physeal dysplasia, radial (Madelung deformity), or ulnar
tags: Forearm hemi-physeal dysplasia, radial (Madelung deformity), or ulnar

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Radial-ulnar (anterior-posterior) axis

info.title: Description
info.content: A group of disorders where there is a premature closure or defective development of one half of the distal radius or ulna. Madelung deformity (as shown above) is due to premature closure of the ulnar third of the distal epiphysis of the radius. This deformity results in a radial shaft that is bowed with dorsal subluxation of the distal radioulnar joint.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: Primary disruption in anterior-posterior (radial-ulnar) patterning. A mutation in SHOX (from either the X, or Y pseudoautosomal region), a forearm- specific gene, has been linked to Madelung deformity; less is known about the mechanism for ulnar hemiphyseal dysplasia.

labels: Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb (Early Patterning)

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Dorsal-ventral axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Condition where palmar structures appear on the dorsal aspect of the hand or forearm, or where dorsal structures fail to develop (absent nails).

info.title: Etiology
info.content: A condition that resulted from a developmental error in the dorsal-ventral axis. This axis is regulated by an area on the dorsal ectoderm that controls the Wnt signalling pathways. This pathway produces Lmx-1 that induces the development of dorsal elements, a process counterbalanced by the gene Engrailed-1. In this condition, disruption to the Wnt pathway led to absent or hypoplastic nails on the dorsal aspect of the hand.

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Dorsal-ventral axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Presence of ectopic dorsal forearm and hand tissues on the volar aspect.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: A condition that resulted from a developmental error in the dorsal-ventral axis. This axis is regulated by an area on the dorsal ectoderm that controls the Wnt signalling pathways. This pathway produces Lmx-1 that induces nail growth, a process counterbalanced by the gene Engrailed-1. In this condition, the lack of Engrailed-1 formation of dorsal elements, I;e;., nails, on the volar aspect of the digit.

labels: Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb (Early Patterning)

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Unspecified axis

info.title: Description
info.content: The affected scapula sits higher on the back than the normal contralateral one. Affected scapula is often underdeveloped and may be fused to the cervical spine. Most common shoulder abnormality in children and may be associated with Poland Syndrome.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: Axis of disruption is not entirely clear, but the AP axis is favored.. The shoulder is a composite structure of mesoderm and neural crest cells. HOX axial positioning controls mesodermal components, but neural crest migration also affects shoulder development. Sprengel deformity is considered neurocristopathy and ectopic ‘omovertebral’ bones are from neural crest cells withn the territory of the trapezius.

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Unspecified axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Congenital abnormality of the shoulder musculature

info.title: Etiology
info.content: Axis of disruption depends on the muscle that is abnormal. Muscle abnormalities are a reflection of abnormal connective tissue patterning. Shoulder connective tissues are a mixture of mesoderm and neural crest cells. HOX axial positioning controls mesodermal connective tissue, but neural crest cell derived connective tisues also direct shoulder muscle attachments.

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - Entire Upper Limb
Unspecified axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Upper limbs display features of lower limb anatomy, could be part of Liberman syndrome: dysplastic elbows with missing olecranon, broadened distal humerus and proximal head of ulna (like femur and proximal tibia). Joint surface of radius and ulna may appear flat (like tibia and fibula). Carpal bones may be fused (like talus), fingers with long metacarpals, like metatarsals.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: To be updated soon

labels: Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - hand plate (Late Patterning)

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - hand plate
Proximal-distal axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Shortening of fingers due to shortened metacarpals or phalanges. Radiograph above shows short 5th metacarpal. Sub-classification: modified Bell’s A-E

info.title: Etiology
info.content: A condition that resulted from a developmental error in the proximal-distal axis. This axis is regulated by the apical ectodermal ridge (AER) and the fibroblast growth factor (FGF) axis. The condition can occur in isolation or as part of a syndrome with several types and an identified genetic locus (see Syndromes). For brachydactyly to happen, a relatively late insult must have happened to the AER during hand plate development. The genes linked to this disorder are associated with digit growth (IHH, PTHLH, BMPR1b, NOG, ROR2, HOXD13) or joint formation (GDF5).

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - hand plate
Proximal-distal axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Condition characterised by shortened upper limb with nubbins or remnant digits. Rudimentary nubbins may be present which could include elements of the nail plate, bone, and cartilage. Typically, the central digits are most affected with relative sparing of the border digits. In this case only the hand plate is affected with sparing of the arm and forearm. Also popularly known as ‘atypical cleft hand’.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: A condition that resulted from a developmental error in the proximal-distal axis. This axis is regulated by the apical ectodermal ridge (AER) and the fibroblast growth factor (FGF) axis. The condition can occur in isolation or as part of Poland syndrome (see Symbrachydactyly - Poland syndrome).  It is postulated there may be a relatively late insult to the AER during hand development, with proximal hand/digit suppression but distal elements containing distal ectodermal elements continue to develop, leading to the formation of ‘nubbins’ (small digits with skin and nail). Suspected primary defect in distal mesoderm underlying the AER, timing of disruption likely dictates degree of terminal loss. Vascular mechanism hypothesized, but molecular deficit not excluded.

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - hand plate
Proximal-distal axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Condition where all elements of the hand plate beyond a certain level are absent, and there is effectively amputation at this level. Note: presence of remnants such as nubbins beyond the level of deficiency suggests a diagnosis of symbrachydactyly rather than transverse deficiency. It is present at 3 levels within the hand plate, and thus can be further subdivided into 3 sub-sections.  IB1iii(a): Wrist (carpals absent/at level of proximal carpals/at level of distal carpals) IB1iii(b): Metacarpals IB1iii(c): Phalangeal (proximal/middle/distal)

info.title: Etiology
info.content: A condition that resulted from a developmental error in the proximal-distal axis. This axis is regulated by the apical ectodermal ridge (AER). Suspected sudden complete loss of AER function. In animal models removal of the AER truncates limbs in a progressive fashion (earlier truncation results in more proximal transverse deficiency). The truncation aborts limb development and no terminal nubbins or phalanges are present.

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - hand plate
Proximal-distal axis

info.title: Description
info.content: A central V-shaped cleft in the centre of the hand due to absence of one or more central digits. Occasional the cleft is either on radial side or less commonly little ulnar side of the hand. Cleft hand usually occur bilaterally, but they can also occur unilaterally. Sometimes called ectrodactyly. An under-developed or hypoplastic thumb may also be present as well as syndactyly.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: Previously thought to be a malformation of unspecified axis, this is now believed to be a result of a defect in the proximal-distal axis. This axis is regulated by the apical ectodermal ridge (AER) and the fibroblast growth factor (FGF) axis. Instead of the ‘cleft’ developing due to an apoptotic process involving an already formed digit, itis now believed to be due to an insult to the AER and actual failure of formation of the digit(s). Of the seven subcategories of SHFM, six have a known genetic basis and all are linked to disruption in apical ectodermal ridge (AER) formation or function. This results in variable loss or even polydactyly of the central digits.

labels: Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - hand plate (Late Patterning)

I-B-2-i.title: Radial Longitudinal Deficiency - hypoplastic thumb
tags: Radial Deficiency (thumb – no forearm or arm involvement)

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - hand plate
Radial-ulnar (anterior-posterior) axis

info.title: Description
info.content: In the absence of forearm/arm involvement, this is also known as thumb hypoplasia. Present in a spectrum varying from small defects to complete absence of the thumb.  Sub-classification thumb (Blauth): I (smaller thumb); II (unstable MCP joint); III (A&B depending on CMC joint); IV (floating thumb); V (absent thumb). Photo above shows a Type V thumb hypoplasia.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: A condition that resulted from a developmental error in the radial-ulnar axis. This axis is regulated by the zone of polarizing activity (ZPA) via the sonic hedgehog (SHH) axis. Most recent updates suggest that suppression of radial growth is the result of increased amounts of SHH from the ZPA and also ectopic SHH on the anterior limb bud. In animal models, disruption in the normal expression of anterior genes (IRX3/5, ALX4, GLI2/3, TWIST1) that counter or regulate SHH expression from the ZPA result in radial deficiency. This includes a decrease in AER-related FGFs and anterior ectopic SHH. This condition would have resulted from a relatively late event in limb development after formation of the forearm structures but before digit formation (compare with radial longitudinal deficiency.

I-B-2-ii.title: Ulnar Longitudinal Deficiency - hypoplastic ulnar ray

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - hand plate
Radial-ulnar (anterior-posterior) axis

info.title: Description
info.content: In the absence of forearm/arm involvement, it is characterised by a deficiency in ulnar-sided structures such as loss of ulnar digits and/or syndactyly

info.title: Etiology
info.content: A condition that resulted from a developmental error in the radial-ulnar axis. This axis is regulated by the zone of polarizing activity (ZPA) via the sonic hedgehog (SHH) axis. Digit formation, closely dependent on the SHH axis, was affected because of an interruption to the ZPA-SHH axis. In animal models, loss of or disruption in SHH expression results in loss of ulna associated digits. The timing and extent of disruption correlates with the associated loss.

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - hand plate
Radial-ulnar (anterior-posterior) axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Presence of an extra digit (or extra digits) on the radial side of the hand (preaxial), otherwise known as thumb duplication. It can vary from a barely visible skin tag to complete duplication or triplication of the thumb. It is the second most common congenital hand disorder. Further divided using Wassel classification.  Sub-classification: Wassel I-VI

info.title: Etiology
info.content: A condition that resulted from a developmental error in the radial-ulnar axis. This axis is regulated by the zone of polarizing activity (ZPA) via the sonic hedgehog (SHH) axis. Most recent updates in animal models suggest that pre-axial polydactyly is the result of increased amounts of SHH from the ZPA and also ectopic SHH on the anterior limb bud, most likely due to increased activity of the long-range limb-specific cis-regulator - zone of polarizing activity regulatory sequence (ZRS). In humans, GLI1 and GLI3 are the functinoal transcription factors of SHH and mutations in these genes is associated with duplicate thumb formation. This condition would have resulted from a relatively late event in limb development.

info.title: Classification
info.content:
Malformations
Abnormal axis formation/differentiation - hand plate
Radial-ulnar (anterior-posterior) axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Congenital malformation where the thumb has three phalanges instead of two and appears more like a finger than a thumb. The extra phalanx may be fully developed, rectangular or shortened and triangular shaped (delta phalanx). Triphalangeal thumbs can be opposable or non-opposable. Can be inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. Classically known as Wassel VI thumb

info.title: Etiology
info.content: A condition that resulted from a developmental error in the radial-ulnar axis. This axis is regulated by the zone of polarizing activity (ZPA) via the sonic hedgehog (SHH) axis. Triphalangeal thumb is a variant of radial polydactyly and most recent updates suggest that both are the result of increased amounts of SHH from the ZPA and also ectopic SHH on the anterior limb bud, most likely due to increased activity of the long-range limb-specific cis-regulator - zone of polarizing activity regulatory sequence (ZRS). Various disruption of the ZPA regulatory sequence (ZRS) causes ectopic anterior (radial) expression of SHH and preaxial polydacty (PPD) type II (triphalangeal thumb); disruption of SALL1 (Townes-Brocks Syndrome) can also cause this phenotype. In animal models, loss of SHH and GLI3 is associated with loss of thumbness in the radial digit, although there is an increase in the number of digits (6-7). Thus, dysregulation of SHH and GLI3 are also suspected.

info.title: Classification
info.content:

Radial-ulnar (anterior-posterior) axis

info.title: Description
info.content: Rare condition, also known as the mirror hand syndrome; characterised by duplication of ulna-sided digits and lack of radial-sided hand structures resulting in an absence of a thumb and ‘mirror-image’ polydactyly.  Sub-classification (Al-Qattan)

info.title: Etiology
info.content: A condition that resulted from a developmental error in the radial-ulnar axis. This axis is regulated by the zone of polarizing activity (ZPA) via the sonic hedgehog (SHH) axis. Most recent updates suggest that ‘ulnarisation’ or mirror-image formation of digits is the result of greatly increased amounts of SHH from the ZPA and also ectopic SHH on the anterior limb bud. The timing and dosage correlate with the extent of duplication.

info.title: Description
info.content: Presence of an extra digit on the ulnar side of the hand (postaxial). Like radial polydactyly, the accessory digit may vary from a well-formed digit (Type A) to a small rudimentary nubbin (Type B)

info.title: Etiology
info.content: A condition that resulted from a developmental error in the radial-ulnar axis. This axis is regulated by the zone of polarizing activity (ZPA) via the sonic hedgehog (SHH) axis. SHH regulates the anterior-posterior patterning through GLI transcription factors. Postaxial polydactyly (PAP) type A1 and B are associated with mutations in GLI3. PAPA8 is associated with mutations in GLI1. Other factors that expand the handplate may also cause this phenotype, as part of a syndrome (see Syndromes)

info.title: Description
info.content: Presence of an ectopic palmar nail at the tip of the finger with evidence of dorsalisation of the palmar skin.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: A condition that resulted from a developmental error in the dorsal-ventral axis. This axis is regulated by an area on the dorsal ectoderm that controls the Wnt signalling pathways. This pathway produces Lmx-1 that induces nail growth, a process counterbalanced by the gene Engrailed-1. In this condition, the lack of Engrailed-1 formation of dorsal elements, I;e;., nails, on the volar aspect of the digit.

info.title: Description
info.content: Appearance of palmar structures on the dorsal aspect of the hand. It can be further classified into three types (mild, moderate, and severe). Should only affect the hand plate to be classified here.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: A condition that resulted from a developmental error in the dorsal-ventral axis. This axis is regulated by an area on the dorsal ectoderm that controls the Wnt signalling pathways. This pathway produces Lmx-1 that induces nail growth, a process counterbalanced by the gene Engrailed-1. In this condition, disruption to the Wnt pathway led to absent or hypoplastic nails on the dorsal aspect of the digit.

info.title: Description
info.content: Congenital fusion of two or more digits. Simple syndactyly: only confined to fusion of the soft tissues whereas complex syndactyly: involve osseous elements. Can be divided into complete (extends to fingertips) and incomplete

info.title: Etiology
info.content: A condition that resulted from a developmental error in an unspecified axis, i.e., not one dominant axis. Digits are formed as separate entities but the soft tissue component between them regressed due to apoptosis, a process controlled by fine balance between fibroblast growth factor (FGF) and bone morphogenetic proteins (BMP). It is believed that the absence of BMP (perhaps due to over-regulation of FGF) prevents apoptosis and leads to syndactyly.

info.title: Description
info.content: Syndactyly is the congenital fusion of two or more digits which may involve bone and soft tissue. Complex syndactyly is where adjacent fingers are connected via an osseous or cartilaginous union.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: A condition that resulted from a developmental error in an unspecified axis, i.e., not one dominant axis. Digits are formed as separate entities except for the syndactylised ones that lead to fusion of the bone. Regression of tissues between digits by apoptosis, a process controlled by fine balance between fibroblast growth factor (FGF) and bone morphogenetic proteins (BMP) fail to separate the digits leading to syndactyly

info.title: Description
info.content: In complicated syndactyly, there are abnormal or accessory phalanges/metacarpals present. The digits may be fused at various levels and in no obvious patterns. All of the digits may be involved.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: A condition that resulted from a developmental error in an unspecified axis, i.e., not one dominant axis. Digits are poorly formed, which led to fusion of bones and soft tissues. Regression of tissues between digits by apoptosis, a process controlled by fine balance between fibroblast growth factor (FGF) and bone morphogenetic proteins (BMP) eventually fail to separate the digits leading to syndactyly

info.title: Description
info.content: Circumferential intrauterine rings or bands which constrict developed tissue resulting in soft tissue grooves. Can be associated with distal lymphoedema or even amputation. Most commonly affects distal extremities such as fingers, but can also affect limbs more proximally, such as the upper arm or forearm. Classification according to Patterson (Types I-IV).

info.title: Etiology
info.content: A condition that resulted from a deformation in already formed digits. The most popular theory is the encircling of digits or limbs with amniotic bands, leading to ring formation or amputation.

info.title: Description
info.content: This condition is characterised by an abnormally large digit(s) or part of digits due to overgrowth of bone and soft tissues. The clinical presentation may be static or progressive. The former refers to an abnormally large digit present at birth, but which grows slowly. Whereas the latter may grow rapidly at a disproportionate rate as the child grows older. May be part of a syndrome (see Syndromes section). Photo above shows static macrodactyly of the middle finger.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: A condition that resulted from disproportionate growth in already formed digits. Macrodactyly can be isolated or part of a syndrome (see Syndrome, e.g., Proteus syndrome). Recent studies have suggested that the enlargement of digits is due to a mosaic mutation in PIK3CA gene, leading to over-regulation of the PIK3CA-AKT pathway.

info.content: Benign vascular tumour of the upper limb present at birth. Intramuscular or deep hemangiomas may not be visible on the skin surface. The majority undergo a period of rapid shrinkage over the first two years of life (rapidly involuting congenital hemangioma, RICH) however they may remain relatively static and visible (noninvoluting congenital hemangioma, NICH)

Unlike hemangiomas, malformations are often not noticed at birth but become more apparent later in life. Clinical picture is highly variable but often presents as a mass.

info.title: Description
info.content: Also known as calcifying aponeurotic fibroma. Distinctive soft tissue fibrous tumour with spotty calcification which usually presents as a painless mass. Typically occurs on the volar surface of the hands and feet in children and adolescents. Despite being a benign tumour, its potentially locally agressive nature and a high recurrence risk, may mimic a malignant process and malignant transformation has been described.

info.title: Description
info.content: Most common form of arthrogryposis multiplex congenital (AMC); the condition is characterised by multiple joint contractures affecting the shoulders, elbows, wrists and hands. There can be lack of elbow flexion and a flexed wrist. Hands are characterized by multiple camptodactylies and thumb-in-palm deformities, similar to distal arthrogryposis (see below). The lower limbs (hips, knees and feet) can also be affected. Other forms of AMC include the syndromic versions and also distal arthrogryposis (see below)

info.title: Description
info.content: In this condition, only the hands are affected with sparing of the elbow and wrist. Hands are characterized by multiple camptodactylies and thumb-in-palm deformities. Most commonly occurs bilaterally. It is important to differentiate distal arthrogryposis from isolated camptodactyly (III-C-2-i): the former affects multiple joints and the latter usually affects the little finger bilaterally with no thumb abnormalities.

info.title: Description
info.content: Condition that causes one or more fingers to be permanently bent due to  a flexion deformity of the proximal interphalangeal joints (PIPJ). All of the volar structures are affected. The fifth finger is commonly affected and often bilateral. There are two onsets: in the newborn and in the adolescent period. It is important to differentiate camptodactyly from distal arthrogryposis (III-C-1-ii) and amyloplasia (III-C-1-i): arthrogrypotic conditions usually present with multiple camptodactylies and thumb-in-palm deformities.

info.title: Description
info.content: Also known as congenital clasped thumb. Due to a spectrum of extensor mechanism abnormalities, usually absent or weak extensor pollicis brevis (EPB). As a result, it is commonly characterised by a flexed and adducted Metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint of the thumb with associated skin tightness in both the index-thumb plane and also the dorsal-volar place (see photo above). It is important to determine if the thumb in palm deformities is part of a wider spectrum of arthrogryposis, which usually presents also with multiple camptodactylies of the fingers (III-C-1-i and III-C-1-ii).

info.title: Hallmarks
info.content: A condition characterised by facial anomalies: malar hypoplasia and ear malformations. Together with radial deficiency, a suggested acronym MER is used: mandibulofacial dysostosis, ear anomalies and radial deficiency.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: In approximately 50% of patients, NAFD has been associated with heterozygous mutations in the SF3B4 gene (1q21.2), coding for a component of the splicing machinery.

info.title: Upper Extremity
info.content: The severity of the limb malformations is proportional to the severity of the mandibular and maxillary deformities. These patients have varying degrees of radial deficiency, often bilateral absence of the radius along with secondary malformed ulna. Proximal radioulnar synostosis is common. There is often thumb hypoplasia or aplasia.

info.title: Hallmarks
info.content: A condition characterised by craniosynostosis, midfacial hypoplasia, complex syndactyly affecting multiple digits of the hands, and complex syndactyly of the feet.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: The condition is due to autosomal dominant mutationmutations in athe fibroblast growth factor receptor gene (FGFR2) on chromosome 10q25–26. The molecular mechanism, which is thought to be related to an uncoordinated differentiation of mesenchyme at the time of skeletalinvolved in cell signalling during embryonic development in both the craniofacial skeleton and the limbs. Advanced paternal age has been associated with de novo mutations, which are found in most cases.

info.title: Upper Extremity
info.content: Complex syndactyly described as three basic types: (1) spade hand; (2) mitten hand; and (3) rosebud hand. Thumbs are usually short with a radial clinodactyly. Usually symphalangism between phalangeal joints with very little movement possible at the digits.

info.content: A condition that affects several part of the body including eyes retinal dystrophy, truncal obesity, learning difficulties and post axial polydactyly.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: The syndrome is a recessive disorder with mutations in genes at several independent loci. BBS is genetically heterogeneous, and to date 18 genes (BBS1-18) have been described. Mutations in known BBS genes account for approximately 70-80% of cases, and triallelic inheritance has been suggested in about 5%.

info.content: Also known as congenital contractural arachnodactyly (CCA), this is a disorder characterized by tall height; long and skinny limbs; long and skinny fingers and toes, multiple joint deformities present at birth usually of the elbows, knees, hips, fingers and ankles; 'crumpled'-looking ears; and curvature of the spine. info.title: Hallmarks
info.content: Very rare condition, CLOVES stand for congenital lipomatous overgrowth, vascular malformations, and epidermal nevi. Affected children present with fatty overgrowth affecting various parts of the body. The affected areas may be covered by capillary malformation. The vascular anomalies vary in severity, and can include lypmphatic or arterio-venous malformations. Limbs when affected can include bilateral or unilateral hypertrophy. Other abnormalities include spinal deformities (scoliosis) or kidney anomalies.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: A rare condition caused by somatic mutations in the PIKC3A gene, and therefore this syndrome belongs to the spectrum of overgrowth condition. PIK3CA-related overgrowth syndromes (PROS) include CLOVES, Proteus and Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome.

info.title: Upper Extremity
info.content: Overgrowth, vascular anomalies. Usually rely on other features to make the diagnosis

info.title: Hallmarks
info.content: A developmental disorder associated with multiple features: slow growth, hirsutism, microcephaly, synophrys (eyebrows that meet in the middle) learning difficulties and limb defects.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: Mutations in three genes involved in chromosomal cohesion (cohesin complex) have been implicated. The NIPBL gene is mutated in approximately 50% of patients and is the major gene involved in the syndrome. Mutations associated with milder forms of the disease have recently been described in the SMC1L1 gene (also called SMC1A; Xp11.22-p11.21), associated with an X-linked form of CdLS, and in the SMC3 gene (10q25).

info.title: Upper Extremity
info.content: The most frequently encountered is ulnar deficiency. Less common: cleft hand, oligodactyly, phocomelia and antecubital pterygium.

info.title: Hallmarks
info.content: Characterized by early fusion of certain skull bones (craniosynostosis). Other signs and symptoms may include wide-set (hypertelorism), bulging eyes (exophthalmos); strabismus (misalignment of the eyes); a small, 'beak-shaped' nose; and an underdeveloped upper jaw. The severity of signs and symptoms can vary among affected people, even within a family. The condition is often confused with Apert’s syndrome.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: Caused by a heterozygous mutation in the FGFR2 gene and inherited in an autosomal dominant manner.

info.title: Upper Extremity
info.content: Carpal fusions had been reported in Crouzon syndrome. It is helpful to know that the incidence of hand anomalies is much higher in Apert than Crouzon syndrome, in order to distinguish between the two.

info.title: Hallmarks
info.content: A relatively common genetic disorder characterised by facial features: flat facies, slanted eyelids and small ears, learning difficulties, cardiac disorders and limb anomalies.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: The syndrome is caused by triplication (trisomy) of chromosome 21.

info.title: Upper Extremity
info.content: Brachydactyly with short phalanges of all digits; stubby hand appearance. There may be occasional clinodactyly and polydactyly. There may be occasional clinodactyly, polydactyly and syndactyly. there is also a higher incidence of a single transverse palmar crease (STPC) otherwise known as a simian crease

info.title: Hallmarks
info.content: Stands for Ectrodactyly-ectodermal dysplasia-clefting syndrome. Presents with clefting of the lip with or without a cleft palate and cleft hand.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: EEC syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder with incomplete penetrance (between 93 and 98%) and variable expression. In over 90% of cases, EEC is due to missense mutations in the sequence of the TP63 gene (3q27) encoding the TP63 transcription factor that is essential for ectoderm and limb development. These cases correspond to the classical EEC syndrome (EEC type 3). The other cases correspond to EEC syndrome type 1, which shows associated clinical features such as malformed auricles and middle and inner ear malformations, and was mapped to 7q21.

info.title: Upper Extremity
info.content: In the cleft hand deformity, there can be severe central clefting leading to syndactyly, oligodactyly and loss of thumb. In EEC, the feet are often affected as well. Both upper and lower extremities often present with bilateral deformities.

info.title: Hallmarks
info.content: Fanconi anaemia (FA) is a condition that affects the bone marrow but can also be associated with radial deficiency and thumb hypoplasia or thumb duplication. Patients can present with typical facial appearances including small head, eyes and mouth.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: FA is due to mutations in genes involved in DNA repair and genomic stability. Biallelic pathogenic variants in one of the 19 genes known to cause autosomal recessive FA.  A heterozygous pathogenic variant in RAD51, known to cause autosomal dominant FA. A hemizygous pathogenic variant in FANCB, known to cause X-linked FA.

info.title: Upper Extremity
info.content: Commonest association of FA: radial deficiency, thumb hypoplasia or thumb duplication.

info.title: Hallmarks
info.content: Otherwise known as focal dermal hypoplasia. The condition affects the skin: very thin skin (dermal hypoplasia), deposits of fat nodules under the skin, or cutis aplasia. Can also affect the skeleton (osteopathia striata: streaks of altered bone density).

info.title: Etiology
info.content: FDH is an X-linked condition caused by mutations in the PORCN gene (Xp11.23), which encodes the porcupine O-acyltransferase, involved in the secretion and signalling of WNT proteins, important for embryonic tissue development.

info.title: Upper Extremity
info.content: Digit involvement is in the form of oligodactyly, syndactyly, polydactyly and camptodactyly. Syndactyly of the toes are also common. Nail dysplasia is also common.

info.title: Hallmarks
info.content: Congenital disorder that affects development of the limbs, head, and face. Findings might include an extra finger or toe, fusion of the skin between the fingers or toes (syndactyly), widely spaced eyes (ocular hypertelorism), and an abnormally large head size (macrocephaly) or high forehead. Features of this syndrome are highly variable, ranging from polydactyly and syndactyly of the upper and/or lower limbs to seizure, hydrocephalus, and intellectual disability.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: Caused by mutations in the GLI3 gene and is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. The GLI3 gene codes for transcription factors (responsible for turning off and on DNA to RNA).

info.title: Upper Extremity
info.content: Polydactyly, syndactyly.

info.title: Hallmarks
info.content: Also known as Acroosteolysis dominant type (AOD), this is a condition characterized by bone abnormalities throughout the body. Signs and symptoms of this disorder vary greatly but may include osteoporosis (loss of bone mass), short stature, compression fractures, skull deformities (prominent occiput), and curvature of the spine (scoliosis). Facial features may include hypertelorism, downward slanting eyes, low set ears and midface hypoplasia. Loss of bone (osteolysis) in the hands and feet is a characteristic feature of this condition. Other features of AOD may include distinctive dental problems, excess body hair, recurrent infections, heart defects, and kidney abnormalities.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: Caused by mutations in the NOTCH2 gene. This gene provides instructions for making a Notch2 receptor which triggers signals important for the normal development and function of many different types of cells

info.title: Upper Extremity
info.content: Brachydactyly due to osteololysis of the bones in the fingers over time.

info.content: This is otherwise known Oculoauriculovertebral spectrum (OAVS) with radial defects, or Goldenhar syndrome with radial defect. Note that there is a condition called Goldenhar syndrome (without the radial defect). The facial features are characteristic: facial asymmetry, ear deformities (microtia), mandibular hypoplasia.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: Most reported cases are sporadic, but there are familial cases that exhibit autosomal dominant inheritance due to trisomy 7 mosaicism.

info.title: Upper Extremity
info.content: Ipsilateral radial deficiency. Thumb anomalies: triphalangeal thumbs, thumb du- plication, thumb hypoplasia, and absent thumb can be associated.

info.content: A condition that affects the heart (atrial septal or ventricular septal defects) and the upper limb.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: The condition is autosomal dominant due to mutation of the TBX 5 gene on chromosome 12q24.21. The TBX5 gene encodes T-box5, a transcription factor regulating the expression of other genes in developing heart and limbs. More than 85% of the clinically diagnosed HOS individuals carry a TBX5 mutation.

info.title: Upper Extremity
info.content: Radial deficiency is most common with varying degrees of associated thumb hypoplasia.

info.title: Hallmarks
info.content: A condition charactersied by short stature, as a result of mesomelia (central part of skeleton is short) and Madelung wrist deformity.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: This is an X-linked dominant inherited condition due to mutations or deletions of the SHOX gene. In around 70 % of cases, LWD is caused by haploinsufficiency of the short stature homeobox (SHOX) gene, which maps to the pseudoautosomal region 1 (PAR1) of the sexual chromosomes (Xp22.33 and Yp11.32). Haploinsufficiency results from heterozygous mutations and deletions of SHOX, or of the downstream PAR1 (where SHOX enhancer elements are located). The molecular defect remains unknown in the remaining 30% of LWD cases.

info.title: Upper Extremity
info.content: Bilateral involvement of the upper extremities with Madelung deformity of the wrist, mesomelia (short forearm), brachydactyly as a result of brachymetacarpia

Joint surface of radius and ulna may appear flat (like tibia and fibula). Carpal bones may be fused (like talus), fingers with long metacarpals, like metatarsals.

info.title: Hallmarks
info.content: Noonan syndrome is a genetic disorder that causes abnormal development of multiple parts of the body. Features of Noonan syndrome include a distinctive facial appearance, short stature, a broad or webbed neck, congenital heart defects, bleeding problems, problems with bone structure (skeletal malformations), and developmental delay.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: The condition is autosomal dominant. In approximately 50% of cases, the disease is caused by missense mutations in the PTPN11 gene (12q24.1), resulting in a gain of function of the non-receptor protein tyrosine phosphatase SHP-2 protein. However other genes from the RAS MAPK pathway (KRAS, SOS1, RAF1 and RIT1) have been identified in a small portion of patients with NS.

info.title: Upper Extremity
info.content: The characteristic feature is clinodactyly.

info.title: Hallmarks
info.content: This is actually a group of related conditions that affect the development of the oral cavity (the mouth and teeth), facial features, and digits (fingers and toes). Researchers have identified at least 13 potential forms of oral-facial-digital syndrome. The different types are classified by their patterns of signs and symptoms. However, the features of the various types overlap significantly, and some types are not well defined. Most forms of this disorder involve problems with development of the oral cavity, facial features, and digits. Most forms are also associated with brain abnormalities and some degree of intellectual disability.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: Only one gene, OFD1, has been associated with oral-facial-digital syndrome and is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern.

info.title: Upper Extremity
info.content: Syndactyly, brachydactyly, clinodactyly, polydactyly

info.title: Hallmarks
info.content: Characterized by generalised skeletal dysplasia which include camptodactyly, long spatulate fingers, short first digits (''tree frog'' hands and feet), pectus carinatum, mild campomelia, mild femoral bowing, limitation of joint movement (elbow extension, wrist abduction) and malformed auditory ossicles leading to conductive hearing loss in some individuals. Additional features include typical craniofacial anomalies (occipital prominence, frontal bossing with prominent supraorbital ridges, flat nasal bridge, hypertelorism, microstomia, dental abnormalities, and cleft palate (pugilistic face)). In affected females, a similar but usually milder spectrum of expressivity is observed.

info.content: This is a spectrum of disorders (4 types) caused by mutations in the gene FLNA (Xq28) that encodes filamin A inherited via a X-linked dominant pattern

info.content: Largely associated with craniosynostosis and associated facial featuresL brachycephaly, maxillary hypoplasia, prominent ear crus. Can also be associated with syndactyly.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: The syndrome has an autosomal dominant disorder and is due to point mutations or deletions involving (or removing completely) the TWIST1 gene (7p21), which encodes a basic helix-loop-helix (bHLH) transcription factor responsible for cell lineage determination and differentiation.  Mutations in FGFR3, FGFR2 and TCF12have been reported to cause synostosis conditions that phenotypically overlap with SCS.

info.title: Upper Extremity
info.content: Simple syndactyly, usually in the second web space.

info.title: Hallmarks
info.content: The hand and foot deformity may present as isolated findings (usually bilateral) or as part of a syndrome affecting other organs, e.g., ectrodactyly-ectodermal dysplasia-cleft lip/palate (EEC, or type 4) as well as deafness and learning disability (type 1).

info.title: Etiology
info.content: Seven subtypes are described (see links). Can be inherited or sporadic, but mostly autosomal dominant although X-linked inheritance have been reported. Various genetic loci are implicated including DLX5 gene (type 1), TP63 gene (type 4) ansd WNT10B (type 6).

info.title: Upper Extremity
info.content: Clinodactyly, brachydactyly, cleft hand with associated thumb abnormalities (narrowed 1st web) and syndactyly (see also Cleft hand under ‘Malformation hand plate proximal distal axis, IB-1-iv)

info.title: Hallmarks
info.content: Thrombocytopenia, bilateral absence of radius and ulna hypoplasia.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: An autosomal recessive condition, due to biallelic mutations in both copies of the RBM8A gene.  This could be due to intragenic mutations or, more commonly, one copy of the gene has a mutation and the other is lost as part of a deleted segment on chromosome 1. The affected individual usually inherits an RBM8A gene mutation from one parent. In about 75% of cases, the affected person inherits a copy of chromosome 1 with the 200-kb deletion from the other parent. In the remaining cases, the deletion occurs during the formation of reproductive cells (eggs and sperm) or in early fetal development. Although parents of an individual with TAR syndrome can carry an RBM8A gene mutation or a 200-kb deletion, they typically do not show signs and symptoms of the condition

info.title: Upper Extremity
info.content: There is bilateral radial deficiency of the radius (100 %) and usually ulnar deficiency as well. The thumb is always present but may be hypoplastic.

info.title: Hallmarks
info.content: A condition characterised by a triad of imperforate anus, abnormally shaped ears, and thumb malformations.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: The condition is described to have an autosomal dominant inheritance, caused by mutation in the gene encoding the SALL1 putative transcription factor, location 16q12.1. Some patients with TBS carry a causative mutation in SALL4 rather than SALL1.

info.title: Upper Extremity
info.content: Pre-axial polydactyly usually in the form of triphalangeal thumb, or duplication.

info.title: Hallmarks
info.content: Characterised by a distinctive facial appearance that includes sparse scalp hair; a rounded nose; a long, flat area between the nose and the upper lip (philtrum); and a thin upper lip. Individuals with this condition also have skeletal abnormalities such as abnormally shaped epiphyses in their fingers and toes and short stature.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: Mutations in the TRPS1 gene localized to chromosome 8

info.title: Upper Extremity
info.content: Clinodactyly, brachydactyly.

info.content: A rare condition affecting apocrine and mammary glands and also ulnar deficiencies.

info.title: Hallmarks
info.content: VACTERL is an acronym for Vertebral defects (including sprengel shoulder, see above), Anal atresia, Cardiovascular anomalies, Tracheoesophageal fistula, Renal abnormalities (such as duplex kidney, see above) and Radial limb deficiency and other Limb anomalies.

info.title: Etiology
info.content: The etiology of VACTERL/VATER is unknown and the association is largely sporadic.

info.title: Upper Extremity
info.content: Radial deficiency is a feature and is often bilateral, including thumb hypoplasia or aplasia. The elbow joint must be examined. Radial polydactyly and syndactyly may be present on the limb opposite the radial deficiency.
